File.Title: The Projection of the Supramammillary Nucleus to the Hippocampal Formation: An Immunohistochemical and Anterograde Transport Study with the Lectin PHA-L in the Rat
File.Authors: LENA HAGLUND, LARRY W. SWANSON AND CHRISTER KOHLER

Abstract.S: The organization and possible neurotransmitter specificity of a projection from the lateral supramammillary nucleus to the hippocampal formation has been examined with immunohistochemical and axonal transport methods in the adult male rat.

Experiments with the retrograde tracer true blue indicate that neurons throughout the rostrocaudal extent of the nucleus are labeled after injections in either dorsal parts of the dentate gyrus and Ammon's horn, or the entorhinal area, although cells labeled by the entorhinal injections tended to occupy more ventral parts of the nucleus.

Combined immunohistochemical-retrograde transport studies showed that a small number ( < 5%) of cholecystokinin-immunoreactive neurons in the caudal tip of the supramammillary nucleus project to the hippocampal formation, as do some (510%) vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP)-immunoreactive neurons throughout the nucleus.
Anterograde transport studies with the lectin phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHA-L) indicate that fibers from the supramammillary nucleus innervate all parts of the hippocampal formation.

Many varicose fibers with terminal boutons were observed in the granular and molecular layers of the dentate gyrus, throughout the molecular layer of field CAB of Ammon's horn, and in the pyramidal layer and stratum oriens of subfield CA3,.
Only scattered fibers were found in fields CAI and CAZ.

Apparent terminal fields were also observed in superficial parts of the molecular layer, and deep parts of the pyramidal layer, of the subiculum, in the deepest layer of the presubiculum and parasubiculum, and in all layers of the entorhinal area.

Introduction.S: It has been known for some time that the medial and lateral mammillary nuclei project massively to the anterior thalamic nuclei, which in turn project to the cingulate gyrus and subicular complex of the hippocampal formation (which also contains the dentate gyrus, Ammon's horn, and the entorhinal area; for nomenclature and review of earlier literature see Swanson et al., '82).
A direct bilateral projection from the supramammillary nucleus to the dorsal part of the hippocampal formation was first observed by Segal and Landis ('74) in the rat with the retrograde HRP method.

This observation has been confirmed in the rat (Pasquier and Reinoso-Suarez, '76; '78; Wyss et al., '79a; Sakanaka et al., '80; Riley and Moore, '81) and monkey (Amaral and Cowan, '801, and the results of combined retrograde transport-histochemical studies indicate that most such neurons contain acetylcholinesterase (Harley et al., '83).
Lena Haglund's present address is Dept. of Medical Nutrition, Karolinska Institute, Stockholm, Sweden.
Christer Kohler's present address is Dept. of Pharmacology, ASTRA Research Laboratories, ASTRA, Sodertalje, Sweden.

ographic studies suggest that this projection ends preferentially in the dentate gyrus of the rat (Segal, 79; Wyss et al., 79b), although an additional input to the region of field CA2 in Ammon s horn has been reported in the monkey (Veazey et al., 82).

There is some electrophysiological evidence to suggest that the input to the dentate gyrus inhibits the firing rate of granule cells (Segal, 791, although it has been shown that the synapses of these fibers contain small spheroidal vesicles and form asymmetric contacts with granule cell bodies and their proximal dendrites (Dent et al., 83).

In the present study we have reexamined the distribution of fibers from the supramammillary nucleus and adjacent regions with the phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHAL) method (Gerfen and Sawchenko, 84).
PHA-L is a lectin that, under appropriate conditions, is transported only in the anterograde direction, and does not appear to be taken up by preterminal axons (fibers-of-passage).
Furthermore, labeled axons are stained with the clarity of Golgi-impregnated material.

This has allowed us to describe in some detail the morphology of fibers from the supramammillary region in the hippocampal formation, and to identify a more widespread innervation than was possible with the autoradiographic method.
Combined retrograde transport-immunohistochemical studies were also carried out to identify possible neurotransmitters in the pathway.

Methods.S: Adult male Sprague Dawley rats were used in all of the experiments.

A combined retrograde transport-immunohistochemical method, described in detail elsewhere (Sawchenko and Swanson, 81), was used to define the topography of neurons in the posterior hypothalamus that project to the hippocampal formation.
It was also used to identify, in so far as possible, the neurotransmitter specificity of the projection.

In brief, injections (50-100 nl of a 2% aqueous suspension) of the fluorescent markers true blue or fast blue (Kuypers et al., 80) were made stereotaxically into either the entorhinal area, or septa1 parts of the dentate gyrus and Ammon s horn, with a 1-pl Hamilton syringe.

After a survival time of 7-14 days, the animals were deeply anesthetized with chloral hydrate, perfused, and the brains prepared as described previously (Sawchenko and Swanson, 81; Kohler et al., 84).
Antisera raised in rabbits against cholecystokinin octapeptide ICCK-8), vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP), and Substance P (SP) were used at a dilution of 1:2,000.
The anti-CCK (Lot No. 25352), and anti-VIP (Lot No. 47411) were obtained from Immunonuclear Corporation, Stillwater, MN, U.S.A.
The anti-SP was kindly supplied by Dr.
Brown (The Salk Institute); its specificity has been described elsewhere (Buck et al., 84 Veening et al., 84).
No staining was obtained when the primary antiserum was replaced by phosphate-buffered saline, or when 1 mg of the homologous peptide was added to 1 ml of a 1:200 dilution of the serum.
The animals were pretreated by injecting 50-150 pg of colchicine into the lateral ventricle 48-72 hours before perfusion to increase immunostaining of cell bodies (see Kohler et al., 84).
The PHA-L method has been described in detail elsewhere (Gerfen and Sawchenko, 83), and we have followed this procedure (see Kohler et al., 84).

In brief, 30-pm-thick frozen sections were cut, and one-in-two series through the injection site, and one-in-ten series through the hippocampal formation were incubated in anti-PHA-L antiserum raised in rabbits (Vector Laboratories) and the antigenantibody complex visualized using an avidin-biotin-complex or an indirect fluorescence method.
Adjacent series were stained with thionin, and these sections were used to make projection drawings for plotting results, and for determining cytoarchitectonic features.
The fluorescence material was viewed with a Leitz Dialux 20 microscope equipped with a Ploem illumination system and a 100-W Hg light source.

The retrograde tracers true blue and fast blue were viewed with filter system A, while the fluorescein-labeled secondary antiserum used to detect anti-PHA-L and other antisera was viewed with filter system Iz (see Kohler et al., 84, for further details).

Results.S: RESULTS
Retrograde transport studies

the distribution of retrogradely labeled cells in the vicinity of the supramammillary nucleus ( see swanson , 82 , for cytoarchitectonic parcellation of this region in the rat ) was determined after injections of true blue into either dorsal parts of the dentate gyrus and field cai of ammon s horn or the medial entorhinal area and parasubiculum .
this was done to guide the placement and interpretation of pha - l injection sites , and to confirm the results of the pha - l experiments ( see below ) .
as shown in figure 1 , retrogradely labeled neurons were found in and around the lateral subdivision of the supramammillary nucleus after injections in both regions .

there was little evidence for a topographically organized projection , although cells labeled by the injections involving dorsal parts of the dentate gyrus and ammon s horn tended to be concentrated dorsal to those labeled by injections centered in the entorhinal area .
the retrogradely labeled cells were morphologically heterogeneous , although small to medium - sized fusiform or bipolar cells were predominant .

as described previously with hrp ( wyss et al . , 79a ) , a much smaller number of retrogradely labeled neurons was found in the same location on the contralateral side of the brain in each experiment .

in the combined retrograde transport - immunohistochemical experiments , a small number of true - blue - labeled neurons ( 5% ) were stained with the antiserum to cck - 8 after injections of true blue into either the dorsal hippocampus or the entorhinal area .

these doubly labeled neurons were of small size and confined to the most caudal part of the lateral supramammillary nucleus at the level of the rostral tip of the ventral tegmental area shown in figure 1f .
in addition , vip - immunoreactive neurons that also contained true blue or fast blue ( 5 - 10% ) after injections in the dorsal hippocampus or entorhinal area were found ( figs . 2 , 3 ) .
these cells were primarily in the caudal two - thirds of the nucleus , although some doubly labeled cells were also found rostrally .
These results were confirmed in ten separate experiments.
no cells doubly labeled with anti - substance p were found .
Anterograde transport studies
the results of nine experiments with pha - l injections that labeled neurons in and around the supramammillary nucleus were examined in detail .
because the pattern of anterograde labeling in the hippocampal formation was similar in many experiments , we shall describe the results by referring to three representative brains .
The results of experiment MAE-20 are illustrated schematically in Figure 4.

the injection of pha - l labeled neurons in the rostral two - thirds of the lateral part of the supramammillary nucleus ( figs . 4 , 5 ) , as well as a few neurons in adjacent parts of the posterior and lateral hypothalamic areas adjacent to the rostral tip of the nucleus .

in this brain labeled fibers were found in all subdivisions of the hippocampal formation on the side ipsilateral to the injection site and in the dentate gyrus and ammon s horn on the contralateral side .

at septa1 ( dorsal ) levels of the hippocampal formation , labeled fibers course through the fimbria on either side of the brain to form plexuses in subfield ca3 , of ammon s horn , and in both the inner and outer blades of the dentate gyrus , where the fibers were concentrated in the granular layer and in immediately adjacent parts of the molecular layer ( fig . 6a ) .

fibers appear to reach the inner blade by coursing from the fimbria through the stratum radiatum of field ca3 ( fig . 7c ) , while those to the outer blade course through the outer limb of the alveus to enter adjacent parts of the blade ( fig . 4b ) .
distinct clusters or patches of labeled fibers were evident in both blades of the dentate gyrus , particularly on the contralateral side ( fig . 6b ) .

occasionally , circumscribed clusters of fibers were observed in more superficial parts of the molecular layer associated with the dentate gyms ( fig . 4a , d ) , and adjacent parts of field ca3 ( figs . 4b - d , 6c ) .

all but the temporal pole of the dentate gyrus contained labeled fibers on the side ipsilatera1 to the injection site ( fig . 4e ) , while only the septa1 onethird to one - half was labeled on the contralateral side .
many of the fibers in the dentate gyrus were varicose , branched profusely , and displayed terminal boutons as defined in golgi material ( fig . 6d ) .
in addition , fibers with many fewer varicosities coursed parallel to the granular layer , in adjacent parts of the molecular layer .
these fibers commonly gave off thin varicose collaterals that descended into the granule layer .
the induseum griseum also contained a moderately dense plexus of varicose fibers and terminal boutons .
these fibers appear to enter rostai parts of the structure in the region where it separates from adjacent parts of the dentate gyrus and ammon s horn ( fig . 4a ) .
the majority of labeled fibers in ammon s horn is centered in the region of subfield ca3a , where terminal plexuses are evident in the pyramidal layer and stratum oriens ( fig . 7a ) .
occasional fibers were also found in fields ca1 and ca2 .
Field CAz was defined according to Lorente de NO ( 34) as a narrow region of large pyramidal cells (adjacent to field CA1) that receives little, if any, mossy fiber input.

the stratum lucidum or mossy fiber layer , was clearly demonstrated in fluorescence sections viewed with darkfield illumination , and the extents of fields cai and ca3 were confirmed in adjacent nissl - stained sections , as mentioned above , the molecular layer of field ca3 also contains a moderately dense plexus of varicose fibers , many of which display terminal boutons .

these fibers were found throughout the septotemporal extent of field ca3 on the ipsilateral side ( fig . 7b ) and reach the molecular layer from the fimbria by passing through the deeper layers of field ca3 .
the distribution of this plexus is particularly clearly illustrated in figure 4d .
very few labeled fibers were found in the molecular layers of field ca3 on the contralateral side of the brain .
in the subicular complex and entorhinal area labeled fibers were confined to the ipsilateral side .
they were found mostly in the superficial part of the molecular layer and in the deeper parts of the pyramidal layer of the subiculum itself ( fig . 4d ) .
in the presubiculum and parasubiculum , occasional plexuses of labeled fibers were found in layer vi ( fig . 4f ) .
at least some labeled fibers were found in all layers of the entorhinal area , although plexuses of varicose fibers were clearly most frequent in the deeper lagers ( iiivi ) ( fig . 4c - g ) .
the injection site in experiment mae - 14 labeled neurons in the caudal third of the supramammillary nucleus and in immediately adjacent parts of the ventral tegmental area ( fig . 8 ) .
A comparison of the injection sites in experiments MAE-20 (Fig. 4) and MAE-14 indicates that they overlapped little, if at all.
Despite this, the overall distribution of labeling in the two brains was remarkably similar (Fig. 8).
There were, however, three differences that warrant discussion.
first , the density of labeled fibers was considerably less in experiment mae - 14 .

it is not clear whether this was due to a smaller injection site in this experiment , or whether fewer cells in the subpopulation that projects to the hippocampal formation were labeled by the injection .

In either case, it seems clear from a comparison of these two experiments that neurons in rostral as well as caudal parts of the supramammillary nucleus project widely throughout the septotemporal extent of the hippocampal formation, a conclusion that is consistent with the retrograde transport experiments (Fig. l), and with all of the other PHA-L experiments that involved the supramammillary nucleus.
second , clusters of labeled fibers were more obvious in the dentate gyrus on the ipsilateral side of the brain in experiment mae - 14 .

after reviewing all of our pha - l experiments , it was clear that smaller injection sites gave rise to more distinct patches of terminal labeling in the dentate gyrus , whereas larger injections led to zones of massive , continuous labeling .
And third, the injection in experiment MAE14 gave rise to more restricted labeling on the contralateral side of the brain.
thus , labeled fibers were restricted to the rostral tip of the dentate gyrus and ammon s horn ( fig . 8a , b ) .

the injection in experiment mae - 19 was centered in the caudal tip of the lateral hypothalamic area , just rostral to the ventral tegmental area , and spread to include a very small number of cells in the rostral part of the supramammillary nucleus ( fig . 9 ) .
the distribution of labeled fibers in this experiment is illustrated in figure 9 .
Two features are worthy of note.
first , very few fibers were labeled in the dentate gyrus and ammon s horn .
these fibers were concentrated in the septa1 half of the structures and formed distinct clusters in the dentate gyrus .
and second , fiber labeling in the entorhinal area was considerably more dense than after any of the injections centered in the supramammillary nucleus itself ( fig . 9c - g ) .

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

The evidence presented here confirms the results of autoradiographic experiments showing that the supramammillary nucleus projects massively and bilaterally to the dentate gyrus (beginning of article.)
In addition, we have shown that the supramammillary nucleus has a much more widespread projection to the hippocampal formation than previously demonstrated.

Thus, the results of the PHA-L experiments indicate that neurons in the supramammillary nucleus project to all parts of the hippocampal formation, although the most dense input is to the dentate gyrus.
This conclusion is based on the morphology of anterogradely labeled fibers.
Thus, each cortical field in the hippocampal formation contained fibers with terminal boutons.
It will be necessary, of course, to demonstrate electron microscopically that these structures indeed form synapses.

However, they are identical in appearance to the terminal boutons seen in Golgi-impregnated material from other parts of the brain that have been examined ultrastructurally (e.g., Rockel and Jones, 73).

Furthermore, there can be little doubt that the labeled terminal boutons seen in the dentate gyrus (Dent et al., 83) and subfield CA3, (Stanfield and Cowan, 84) correspond to the synapses observed in electron microscopic autoradiographs after 3H-amino acid injections in the supramammillary region of the rat.
The distribution of labeled fibers in different parts of the hippocampal formation is distinctive.

They are concentrated in the granular layer and immediately adjacent parts of the molecular layer of the dentate gyrus, in the molecular layer of field CA3 as a whole, and the pyramidal layer and stratum oriens of subfield CA3, in particular.

In the subiculum, labeled fibers and terminal boutons are concentrated in superficial parts of the molecular layer and in deeper parts of the pyramidal layer, while they seem to be restricted to the deepest layers of the presubiculum and parasubiculum.
All layers of the entorhinal area contain labeled fibers.
Perhaps the most interesting feature of the input to the dentate gyrus is that it forms irregularly spaced patches when only small numbers of cells in the supramammillary nucleus were injected.

On the other hand, dense, continuous labeling was found with larger injections, although even here patches were frequently observed in the contralateral dentate gyrus, and along the periphery of continuously labeled areas on the ipsilateral side.

This evidence suggests that small numbers of cells, or perhaps individual cells, in the supramammillary nucleus give rise to circumscribed terminal fields in the dentate gyrus, and thus presumably influence circumscribed groups or patches of granule cells.
This raises the possibility of rather complex influences on hippocampal circuitry, which would depend in turn on the pattern of neural inputs to individual cells in the supramammillary nucleus.

The lateral supramammillary nucleus contains cells that cross-react with antisera against cholecystokinin octapeptide (Greenwood et al., '821, vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (Hokfelt et al., '821, and substance P (present study).

Fibers stained with antisera against these peptides have been observed in the hippocampus (Vincent et al., '81; Greenwood et al., '82; Hokfelt et al., '82) and in our retrograde tracing experiments a small number of CCK-8 and VIP immunoreactive cells were found to project to the hippocampal formation.
While the CCK-8 doubly labeled cells were found caudal and ventral in the supramammillary nucleus, the VIP-stained cells were scattered through all rostrocaudal levels of the nucleus.
In fact, the very caudal position of the CCK-8 cells indicates that they may form a rostral continuation of CCK-8-stained neurons in the ventral tegmental area.
Very few retrogradely labeled cells were stained with the CCK-8 antiserum.

This is in agreement with biochemical findings (Handelmann et al., '81) that transections of hippocampal afferents resulted in small (if any) measurable reductions of hippocampal CCK-8 immunoreactivity.

The fact. that CCK-8 and VIP accounted for less than 20% of the total number of retrogradely labeled cells indicates that some other neurotransmitter candidate may be contained within the supramammillary projection to the hippocampal formation.
One such candidate is SP.

Interestingly, a recent study (Gall and Selawski, '83) has shown that SP immunoreactive cells from the supramammillary region project to the hippocampus in the guinea pig, although in the present study we did not find evidence for such a projection in the rat.
However, we have noted (unpublished observation) that SP-stained fibers are restricted to field CA3 in Ammon's horn and are not found in the dentate gyrus.
Therefore, since our retrograde dye injections were confined to field CAI and the dentate gyrus, we may not have labeled SP-stained neurons in the supramammillary nucleus.

Apart from possible species differences, it is also possible that differences in SP antisera used may explain these discrepancies, but since the visualization of CCK-8, VIP, and SP in the supramammillary nucleus is dependent on extensive colchicine treatment of the rats this question merits further investigation.

In any case, it seems likely that the projection from the lateral supramammillary nucleus (SUMl) to the hippocampal formation contains at least three different neuroactive substances, and further work is needed to determine whether each gives rise to a unique distribution of terminals.
The afferent control of the supramammillary nucleus is poorly understood.
However, it is undoubtedly very complex.

The nucleus lies within the course of the medial forebrain bundle, and it seems likely that at least some of the ascending and descending fibers in the bundle end in, give rise to collaterals that end in, or establish synapses en passant in the nucleus.
Autoradiographic evidence in the rat suggests that most inputs to the supramammillary nucleus descend through the medial forebrain bundle from more rostral sites in medial parts of the forebrain.

Thus, patterns of silver grains suggestive of terminal fields have been described after 3Hamino acid injections in the prelimbic area of the frontal cortex (Beckstead, '79), which receives an input from the mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus, the medial septaldiagonal band complex and lateral septal nucleus (Swanson and Cowan, '791, the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (Swanson, '76; Swanson and Cowan, '79), the medial preoptic area (Swanson, '76), and the substantia innominata and lateral preoptic and lateral hypothalamic areas (Swanson, '76; Saper et al., '791, which has also been confirmed with the PHA-L method (Swanson et al., '84; Mogenson et al., '84).

Since the lateral septal and bed nuclei receive massive inputs from Ammon's horn and the subiculum (see Swanson and Cowan, '771, and the bed nucleus also receives a massive input from the amygdala (see Krettek and Price, '78), these results taken together suggest that the supramammillary nucleus may receive information from widespread parts of the limbic region of the telencephalon, as well as from other parts ofthe hypothalamus.
Interestingly, almost all of the regions just mentioned also project to the medial and/or lateral mammillary nuclei (Swanson, '76; Swanson and Cowan, '77, '79; Saper et al., '79).

Therefore, the major difference between inputs to the medial and lateral mammillary nuclei taken together, and the supramammillary nucleus, is that the former receive a massive direct input from the subicular complex by way of the fornix, while the latter does not (Swanson and Cowan, '77).

The only ascending input to the supramammillary nucleus for which there is reasonable autoradiogaphic evidence arises in the dorsal and median nuclei of the raphe (Conrad et al., '74; Taber Pierce et al., '76; Bobbilier et al., '791, although a dopamine-0-hydroxylase-immunoreactive (presumably noradrenergic) terminal field in and around the supramammillary nucleus has been described (Swanson and Hartman, '75).

It would appear, therefore, that the supramammillary nucleus receives descending inputs from a variety of limbic and hypothalamic regions and ascending inputs from the midbrain raphe nuclei and brainstem noradrenergic cell groups.
Nevertheless, almost nothing is known about the functional significance of the widespread projection from this nucleus to the hippocampal formation.

It does seem clear that fibers from the supramammillary nucleus can influence the firing rate of granule cells in the dentate gyrus, and it is tempting to suggest that the nucleus is one of a series of brainstem cell groups that modulate or "gate" the flow of information through the trisynaptic circuit of the hippocampal formation (Winson, '81).

Finally, it should be pointed out that axonal transport studies indicate that the supramammillary nucleus has rather widespread projections, in addition to the pathway to the hippocampal formation described here.

These projections include inputs to the anterior limbic area of the cingulate gyrus (Carter and Fibiger, '77; Swanson, '82), lateral septal nucleus (Carter and Fibiger, '77; Veazey et al., '82; Swanson, '821, amygdala (Carter and Fibiger, 77; Swanson, '82) and locus coeruleus (Swanson, '82).
Clearly, a great deal remains to be learned about the organization and functional significance of circuitry associated with the supramammillary nucleus.
